Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "On nuget.org the versions of Microsoft.ChakraCore are incorrect when read from the APIs" (#7863) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
On nuget.org, the versions reported by the API differs from the versions reported by the web interface for Microsoft.ChakraCore

### To Reproduce
Using a browser, visit https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.ChakraCore/
You can see the latest version is 1.11.16 (confirmed)

Using curl, access the information about the library:
https://api.nuget.org/v3/registration3/microsoft.chakracore/index.json
You can see the latest version is 1.11.15

### Expected behavior
The versions reported from the web interface and the versions reported from the API are consistent.

### Screenshots
**WEB:**  
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/186370/76203510-ac5b5980-61ee-11ea-8f31-46a98e23c270.png)

**API:**  
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/186370/76203565-c72dce00-61ee-11ea-966a-571b9fc6272e.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Expose domain and diagnostics source in MEF container" (#7862) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
This enables synchronous initialization (via the constructor) of the cookie compliance shim.
Also, move the refresh to the background so that initial start-up is not slowed down.

Fully lights up with https://nuget.visualstudio.com/NuGetMicrosoft/_git/NuGet.Shims/pullrequest/1342.
Related to https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/2980.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Reject broken ZIPs on API push with better message" (#7859) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Address https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/3046

This was a little tricky to repro locally, when reading a ZIP of disk because the behavior of `FileStream` and `HttpInputStream` (the stream from an ASP.NET file upload) is different. `FileStream` does not throw when you seek out of bounds. It only throws when you read. `HttpInputStream` throws when you seek out of bounds, thus the `ArgumentOutOfRangeException` we see on server side.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Download count isn't updated when self-hosting in IIS" (#7861) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: I have configured a instance of NuGet Gallery running under IIS using SQL Server as the database.  The download count doesn't appear to updating regardless of whether the download is via NuGet Install-Package or through the package download link on the website.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "XPlat Signing: Rebase onto dev again" (#9285) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: There were some fairly large changes in dev, including a major revert that definitely caused a lot of conflicts for us.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Make IOutputConsole async" (#9268) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
IOutputConsole is currently sync. The reason for that is that it was original designed when PMC was the primary Visual Studio scenario & async code was not as common.

Many of our codepaths currently invoking the output console are async and with https://github.com/nuget/home/issues/8673 that's becoming even more important. 

Refactor IOutputConsole to contain only async methods.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Sort packages by ID in the Updates tab of the Package Manager UI" (#9278) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: VS UI

NuGet version: 5.4.0

VS version: 16.4.5

OS version: Windows 10 v1903 (18362.693): 

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: No

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Open a project with packages that can be updated.

2. Open the Package Manager UI for the solution or the project.

3. Choose the Updates tab.

The packages are listed in a seemingly random order, making it harder to find specific packages. It would be useful if the packages were sorted by their ID, as is already the case in the Installed tab.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1618054/76198300-1fb09b80-61ee-11ea-97bb-1beb0bae434c.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1618054/76201867-3e199580-61f4-11ea-846b-7dcc4a2a7523.png)

Related: #2585 tracks a broader issue regarding sorting, including [a Developer Community report](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/56659/nuget-management-window-nuget-updates-can-not-be-s.html) about default sorting of the Updates tab.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Re-enable OSX failing signing tests" (#9013) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
These 4 tests seem to behave differently on Mojave vs Sierra. On Sierra chain building fails in signing, while in Mojave signing succeeds but then verification fails with the OCSP server issues.
The chain building issues in Sierra seem similar to the issues in the 18 other tests that don't repro in Mojave, so they might be related.

The tests have been disabled on CI and need to be fixed and re-enabled.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Test ExtractPackageAsync_RequireMode_UnsignedPackage_InCoreCLR_SkipsSigningVerificationAsync is out of date when xplat verification is implemented" (#9008) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Test ExtractPackageAsync_RequireMode_UnsignedPackage_InCoreCLR_SkipsSigningVerificationAsync is checking if unsigned package will skip verification in CoreCLR in RequireMode during extraction(restore).
This test should be disabled for netcore5.0 when xplat verification is implemented, as the signed package should be verified.

We need to make sure the verification xplat is tested when we disable this test.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Analyze existing ecosystem for signature validity" (#9028) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: We need to run some azure functions to go over the entire NuGet registry and make sure all packages have valid signatures, and that our xplat verification actually works on them, on all platforms. Fix bugs accordingly.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Broken test in  SignatureUtilityTests(functional test)" (#8937) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: In  SignatureUtilityTests(functional test), GetTimestampCertificateChain_WithNoSigningCertificateUsage_Throws failed on Windows(netcore), Linux and Mac

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Azure Devops Build Fail when using GeneratePathProperty true for PackageReference" (#9284) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet product used NuGet.exe 
NuGet version : 4.3.0
VS version (if appropriate): Visual Studio 2019
OS version: Widows 2019 Azure Hosted Agent
Worked before? No

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

We have set up a Project in Visual Studio where we are using NuGet Packages references. For one of the NuGet Packages we are setting the GeneratePathProperty to true, so that we can copy the files from the NuGet package location to the Output bin folder of our Project

He have configured the .csproj file as below:

<PackageReference Include="ilmerge" GeneratePathProperty="true">
  <Version>3.0.29</Version>
</PackageReference>
<None Include="$(Pkgilmerge)\tools\net452\ILMerge.exe">
  <Link>ILMerge.exe</Link>
  <CopyToOutputDirectory>Always</CopyToOutputDirectory>
</None>
<None Include="$(Pkgilmerge)\tools\net452\System.Compiler.dll">
  <Link>System.Compiler.dll</Link>
  <CopyToOutputDirectory>Always</CopyToOutputDirectory>
</None>
This works perfectly fine locally (using Visual Studio 2019) - project compiles and files are copied to the bin folder, however in our Build Pipeline using the windows-2019 hosted agent (that should also have VS 2019 as per the documentation https://github.com/actions/virtual-environments/blob/master/images/win/Windows2019-Readme.md) this fails during the Build Task:

[error]C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Enterprise\MSBuild\Current\Bin\Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets(4601,5): Error MSB3030: Could not copy the file 'd:\tools\net452\ILMerge.exe' because it was not found.

[error]C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio\2019\Enterprise\MSBuild\Current\Bin\Microsoft.Common.CurrentVersion.targets(4601,5): Error MSB3030: Could not copy the file 'd:\tools\net452\System.Compiler.dll' because it was not found.

The Build Definition has following tasks

steps:
- task: NuGetToolInstaller@0
- task: NuGetCommand@2
  displayName: 'Restore Nugets'
  inputs:
    restoreSolution: '$(solutions)'
    vstsFeed: 'Project-Packages'

- task: VSBuild@1
  inputs:
    solution: '$(solutions)'
    platform: 'Any CPU'
    configuration: 'Release'
    logProjectEvents: false

- task: PublishBuildArtifacts@1
  inputs:
    pathtoPublish: '$(Build.StagingDirectory)'
    artifactName: $(pluginName)
  condition: always()

Any ideas what could be the issue or what we need to change in order for the build in Azure DevOps to work?

Thank you

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Default package source name has format placeholder residue" (#9277) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Noticed while experimenting during #9251 with the preview of 3.1.200 SDK:
```
$ dotnet nuget add source https://ci.appveyor.com/nuget/gitversion-8nigugxjftrw --configfile NuGet.config
Package source with Name: Package source {0}1 added successfully.

$ dotnet nuget list source --configfile NuGet.config
Registered Sources:
  1.  nuget.org [Enabled]
      https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json
  2.  Package source {0}1 [Enabled]
      https://ci.appveyor.com/nuget/gitversion-8nigugxjftrw

$ cat NuGet.config
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <disabledPackageSources>
    <clear />
  </disabledPackageSources>
  <packageSources>
    <clear />
    <add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" />
    <add key="Package source {0}1" value="https://ci.appveyor.com/nuget/gitversion-8nigugxjftrw" />
  </packageSources>
</configuration>

$ dotnet nuget remove source "Package source {0}1" --configfile NuGet.config
Package source with Name: Package source {0}1 removed successfully.
```
The default package source name has format placeholder residue; i.e. `{0}` in the name.

This comes from [Source_DefaultNamePrefix](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/a746cd6a01dfd22187375ee9c5a0d9b98676020a/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Commands/Strings.resx#L962-L965) and is used in [AddSourceRunner.Run](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/a746cd6a01dfd22187375ee9c5a0d9b98676020a/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Commands/SourcesCommands/SourceRunners.cs#L20-L36) without `string.Format`, so the format placeholder residue is left in place. Looks like a bug to me! üòâ

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Test Failure] Embedded icon of the package creating by nuget.exe can‚Äôt be shown in PM UI with local package feed" (#9225) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem
NuGet version: NuGet Client Dev\5.6.0.6472
VS Version: Master\29825.171
OS: Windows-10-Enterprise-RS5
## Detailed repro steps
1.	Create a Class Library (.NET Framework 4.8) in VS and build the solution.
2.	In the Developer Command Prompt for VS, create a nuspec file by executing command ‚Äúnuget spec‚Äù
3.  Make an image file (size limited to 1 MB with JPEG/PNG format and 128x128 resolution) and locate in the package.
4.  Add following to nuspec file.
```
<package>
  <metadata>
    ...
    <icon>images\icon.png</icon>
    ...
  </metadata>
  <files>
    ...
    <file src="..\icon.png" target="images\" />
    ...
  </files>
</package>
```
5.  Pack the package to local path by executing command ‚Äúnuget pack‚Äù.
6.  Create a C# Console App (.NET Framework 4.8) in VS and open the PM UI of the project.
7.  Add the package source as a local feed in Settings->NuGet Package Manager->Package Sources.
8.  Select the new added local feed in the Package source dropdown box in the PM UI and install the package.

## Expected
The embedded icon show correctly in all the tabs of PM UI.
## Actual
The embedded icon can‚Äôt be shown in all the tabs of PM UI. as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/75345053-e8c9b400-58d6-11ea-8a4b-0c9f2a076604.png)
## Note
1.	It doesn‚Äôt repro for the package creating by ‚Äúdotnet pack‚Äù with local package feed.
2.	It doesn‚Äôt repro for the package ‚ÄúText2Xml.Lib‚Äù (version 1.1.1 and 1.1.2) in remote feed.
3.	It also repro with icon.jpg.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Ensure Static Graph restore is available in dotnet.exe" (#9267) at NuGet/Home

This basically means ingesting https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Console/NuGet.Build.Tasks.Console.csproj into the SDK.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Clarify TargetFramework vs TargetFrameworks vs TargetFrameworkMoniker across the NuGet codebase." (#8388) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "Remove temporary WorkaroundNetStandard target from common.targets" (#8364) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Related issue: https://github.com/dotnet/cli/issues/11378
The above issue is already fixed in VS 2019 16.2 preview2. 
But we don't have the latest version of VS on VSEng-MicroBuildVS2019 agent pool (the current version is 16.1.6). So we have to add a temporary WorkaroundNetStandard target to common.targets to make the build pass.

We need to remove this WorkaroundNetStandard target from common.targets when the VS on agent pool VSEng-MicroBuildVS2019 has that fix.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Deprecating TLS 1.0 and 1.1 on NuGet.org ‚Äì Stage 1" (#42) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
## NuGet.org will temporarily remove support for TLS 1.0/1.1 on February 26, 2020

We plan to temporarily remove support for TLS 1.0/1.1 across 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each, to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. If you discover that you are impacted and cannot identify a workaround, please open an issue on the NuGet Gallery GitHub repo.

Read this blog post to learn more and to identify the test slot time in your time zone - https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/deprecating-tls-1-0-and-1-1-on-nuget-org-stage-1/
